A- Body is thick and solid motor oil black. Pours with a 1 finger foamy dark brown head that has good retention and some lacing is left behind in the glass.

S- Awesome, exceptional, and unexpected for an imperial stout. The highlight is a huge spiciness-hot pepper and a hint of cinnamon. This is really in balance with rich bittersweet dark chocolate, anise and licorice.

T- Upfront is an accent of spiciness over prominent roasted malt and rich dark chocolate. Some anise is in the background. The finish is quite smooth and adds a hint of vanilla sweetness. A slight alcohol heat lingers.

P- Medium carbonation with a smooth, syrupy, and exceptionally smooth and creamy body.

O- I am very impressed with this brew. Has to be one of my top stouts. I love the addition of cinnamon and hot pepper and think it compliments the stout qualities very well. Would love to have this one again!

Serving type: bottle

A: Quite an ominous pour from the bottle. Viscous and black, creating a sturdy mocha head in the glass.

S: I was worried that the chili peppers would overwhelm the beer, but they provide only a subtle spice to the beer which works nicely with the sweet components. Chocolate and vanilla, along with caramel and roasted malts complete the nose.

T: A much more balanced flavor than the BA version offers. An inviting sweetness up-front of chocolate and vanilla, followed by a touch of bitterness and spice (chili and cinnamon) on the back end.

M: A very thick and chewy feel on the tongue. The carbonation is minimal, as it should be and just helps to enhance the creaminess.

D: The alcohol is nowhere to be found, but this one does pack quite the punch. A fantastic stout and one of the first CCB beers Ive been really impressed by.

UPDATED: MAR 3, 2012 Pours deep black with spare tan head, aroma is big chocolate, wine, vanilla, and pepper.  Taste is a bit thin and soft but has a nice chocolate start that goes into the vanilla and finishes dry and peppery.  Nicely done beer, easily my favorite out of their line up.

750 ml bottle via trade with smith4498 - I actually got to try this a couple weeks when Dak brought a bottle down to my BBQ.  I wasnt worried about rating it since I had a bottle in the back fridge.  It was really good that day.  Now, Im cracking open the 750 to drink all by myself.  It pours a solid black color with a small brown head.  After a good swirl, light spotty lacing is left behind along with a fine tan film left after the swirl.  Aroma is roasted malt, light chocolate and coffee, dark esters, and a touch of vegetables.  Flavor is sweet chocolate, roasted malt, esters, and light spice.  Cant detect the vanilla.  Finish is roasted chocolate that leaves the lips smackin.  Medium to full body.  A pretty damn nice beer.  Thanks Dak and Jason.

Bottle thanks to Maltzilla!Black, head darker than cardboard. Green nose of pepper, too harsh for the sweet chocolate and light vanilla background and the contradiction is at once vegetal and ashy. Taste is a bit better, more balance than the nose with the pepper taking a backseat. Still, its rather straightforward sweetness in chocolate and vanilla, not much nuance or integration. A collection of flavors in balance, some working some not, and overall not very well integrated.

Bottle:  The aroma consists of cocoa, milk chocolate, and a hint of cinnamon.  It pours a dark brown with a moderate brown head...really impressive looking.  The flavor with dark chocolate.  Light-moderate dark fruits in the middle.  In the finish the chocolate turns more to cocoa and milk chocolate with some light-moderate roasted.  Full bodied with mild carbonation and slightly oily mouthfeel.

UPDATED: DEC 28, 2010 A-pours a viscous jet black color with a dark mohagony colored dense head. huge thick velvety lace

S-the nose brings something different every time I swirl it. the chilies and pepper notes will show through on one. the cocoa nibs on another, a good bit of roasted malts throughout with a touch of vanilla. anise and molasses in the back with a touch of dark fruits. hints of fusel alcohol in the back but still solid.

T-the pepper spice is right up front, roasted malts, dark chocolate and vanilla behind. the cinnamon comes in towards the back with a fair bit of dark fruity sweetness to close the deal. lots going on here and it works fairly well together.

M-this is very smooth on the palate, full bodied and slightly dry in the back. so soft in my mouth. just enough carb to allow this to fall softly down the throat.

D-this has some interesting stuff going on, the sweetness is very nice in the back to balance the peppery spice up front. it is a well done contrast with a nice balance to it.  not something I can drink a ton of but still a tasty brew!

UPDATED: JUN 21, 2013 bottle at chris -o ... deep black ... no head ... spicy peppery roast malt nose ... big soft roast ... coffee and toffee ... some vanilla ... little coconut ... good solid roast ... only a little chilli ... best so far today ... br br ... deep black ... thin tan head ... big heavy roast malt ... little capsicum nose ...
Bottle at chrisO 2012 ... deepblack ... thin tan head ...deep meaty chocolate malt ... big chocolate ... soft toffee ... dark roast ... choclstr ... nice chilli spice 4.2

Bottle at home ... thanks to Ben ... Deep black ... thin tan lacing ... deep rich malts ... soft mellow but huge coconut ... light chilli ...light lime nose...  sweet dark roast malts ... chewy malts ... light cocount... light chilli ... 4.3 again ... lovely

Bottle, huge thanks to Andy (puzzl) for this one! Poured black. Lets face it, even with a VLT youre seeing nothing other than black in this, other than the sparse layer of mid brown bubbles. Huge and roasty, chocolatey, some smokey notes and hints of sweet vanilla on the aroma. Quite a beast on the tongue, packed with big smokey, roasted flavours and loads of bittersweet chocolate, sprinkled with vanilla. So bloody smooth on the tongue, really something else indeed! Smooth, thick and coating with a fantastic depth and lingering dry malt bitterness. A touch of spicey heat in the back gives more animation on the palate.

Pours jet black with a thick tan head. smoky, dark chocolate aromas. Extremely smooth flavours of chocolate, coffee, vanilla, slightly peppery. Wonderful roasty, toasty long lingering mouthfeel. Smoky, dry as a bone finish with plenty of  warming alcohol. Lovely stuff! Big cheers to Andy for this one!

(bottle - 750 ml) Thick and dark black pour with a thick and sticky tan head with incredible lacing. Coats the glass like syrup. Roasty aroma with a lot of chocolate and vanilla sweetness. Some very light spice and molasses as well. Flavor starts with a heavy and chewy roasted note followed up by a very nice and semi-sweet cocoa and vanilla flavor. The alcohol warms it up and really helps to enhance the sweetness of the cocoa and the chocolate. A little coffee comes through near the end. I didnt taste a whole lot of the peppers, but this is simply an outstanding and very solid all-around stout.

Thanks to Andy. Excellent on the palete. Incredibly smooth. No nonsense high abv imperial stout. Nice smokey raunchbier style and subtle, chocolate aroma. Great smooth, fruity, herbal texture, soo smooth. Caramel body, chocolate, roasted malts and leather. A really solid brew. This is a big beer. Enjoy, in good measurements! Cheers Andy.

A Mes rate. Bottle at the Cask, big thanks to Andy.Black as night with a very good brown head. A little cheesy and funky on the nose with a slight vegetable note. Not an amazing aroma if Im honest. Once in the mouth however, everything changes. This is excellent stuff. A big chewy US impy stout with a really unusual but absolutely glorious smoky character. Amazing fruity stuff, yeast is obvious but really good, lots of American chocolate and some really tasty herbal and spicy hints. A little swift in the finish for the style but its not a problem, you just drink more. Love it.

Bottle shared by moejuck. Black pour with a tan head. Aroma of chocolate, spice, a bit of roast and nuts. Flavors were nice, lots of spicy notes that didnt overwhelm and gave a distinct character to the beer and the sweet/roasted notes gave a balance to those spicy characteristics. Nice mouthfeel, full bodied and had a satisfying finish, no real noticeable booze. Overall, tasty brew that did really well with the smoked chocolate ice cream we dumped into it.

Pours black with a very nice dark brown head. Sticks around and laces the glass beautifully. Not very aromatic given what is in it. I mostly just sense the alcohol in the nose and get a bit of hops, and a little bit of the peppers. The taste is a mixed bag; sweet with a bit of alcohol warming the back-end; a little pepper bite on the tip of my tongue and thats it for the spice; bit of chocolate and a hint of vanilla. Every now and then there is a slight burn in the back of my throat to remind me that there is peppers in this, but ever so slight. Very viscous and coats the tongue and mouth very nicely. Silky smooth. This is up there with the best in Imperial stouts, and a couple notches above DL.

Bottle.  
Huge thanks to two peoples efforts for me to try this brew.  Thank you brewhopperjay on BA and another big thanks to my girlfriend to hauling this to me in Geneva...and of course she is splitting it with me :).  

Really dense jet black oily pour and like an oil slick in a glass.  Denser tan head that just leaves a patchy tan film on top.  A lot of dark, nearly bitter chocolate in the aroma at first, then the peppers come in a little with more roasted coffee aromas than anything.  I really love how this brew is barely sweet at all to my palate.  Lots of dry, roasted qualities.  Love the spice on top of the dense coffee and chocolate and very much enjoyed the bit of burn at the back of my throat from the pepper and alcohol combo.  An awesome brew, and I have to say it lives up to the hype for me.

I would like to start off by giving a huge thanks to fata2683 for this beer.  This is such a generous gift from my friend in the pan handle.  Pured into a tulip.  Of course it poured a thick, black with a dark tan head.  taste is very complex. very dry and bitter.  Peppers do come through at the end.  Very thick and smooth mouthfeel.  This is an awesome beer.

Super thick, syrupy and black as night.  The aroma jives pretty closely with the flavor - dried hot pepper, cocoa powder, coffee and spices.   Definitely has a subtle kick from the peppers and a good amount of sweetness.  Quite complex, ridiculous and extreme but still avoids being a chore to drink.

#1800! Huge thanks to my boy drowland for this overfilled bottle of joy. Poured delictibly into my Cigar City snifter. Appearance has a thick thick black hue with a heavy bread-loaf brown head. Lots of stuff going on in the nose. Roasted coffee notes blend well with the spice of the chilis. Some vanilla aged wood also. Damn this is crazy already. Coating mouthfeel. Thick black coffee flavor with roasted nuts and malts. The peppers in this provide for a gentle mix of new and unique flavors. They also give the slightest kick which continues into the finish. Some dry bitterness on the finish, mainly attributed to the roasted notes. Fantastic, theres no doubt about it.

bottle-HUGE thanks to Daknole for bringing what is my first Cigar city beer ever.  pitch black with a nice kacki colored head with huge legs on the glass.  huge nose of the whole kitchen sink of impy stout aromas-coca, chocolate, roast, oak, vanilla, anise-WOW!  this is really complex!  deep, sweet, big char flavors along with notes of lite pepper, huge dark chocolate.  big alcohol here, but not really detracting at all.  Its well integrated into the complexity of this beer.  this is one mangler for sure-i would be dead after a 750 of this either by diabetic shock  or alcohol poisoning.  This could be the best impy stout i have ever had minus FFF 04 dark lord.

750ml bottle, pours a very viscous black with a big creamy dark chocolate head.  Big nose of cocoa dusted chilie peppers a liitle less coffee than expected. Very creamy and thick on the palate. Light chilie spice, toasted cocoa and fresh coffee.
Wow. Creamy. Chocolate. The chili is there as it interacts with the chocolate. Very rich and thick. Quite intense.
Had on cask  at red-light red-light. Smells of cigars, hops, and grass.  Very murky and deep brown. Its an amazing, if not perfect, imperial stout.

750ml From Kingdom Liquors. Pours really dark chocolate brown and thick with some light lacing. Initial reaction was wow is this smoky! Body is full and velvety soft. Oily and with low carbonation. Finish is a light bitternesss, really faint which is surprising to me. Cocoa is the star here with a pleasant supporting cast of vanilla, ancho and cinnamon in that order. The alcohol is hidden well yet warms in the finish. Dark chocolate with the hint of ancho isa  really nice flavor. This is so easy to drink I think it could be dangerous at least for me. Overall this is the most enjoyable of the style I have ever had in my recollection. If I were able to, I would give palate a 7 out of 5. Kudos.
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text:
On draft at redlight redlight
dark, smokey, smooth as butter, heavy
a nice mocha hued head first appears but quickly vanishes
I dig it

Sampled @ dld 2010 thanks to LT. Dan no it wasnt a FULL PINT poured as black as any RIS with nice tight tan head aromas  were of roasted malts.chocolates,vanilla and peppers wow taste was of an RIS with  cinnamon and peppers well it might not be the best RIS that I have had but it is a bad ass pepper beer with just a little heat coming coming thourgh well now i know

Great RIS and the flavors keep popping through. I really didny get any of the pepper notes but maybe just a slight hint in the very end. I guess i was expecting a little more there but the other flavors came shining through. Great vanilla, cocoa,and yes some cinnamon notes along with the barrel aging lend to the complex blend that works great for this style. Up to this point i was disappointed with CCBs  beers but this one is a winner. Great beer and worth seeking out. Im going to celler a couple of these and see what time does for them!

I went into the experience expecting an "out of body" type of moment, and thats pretty much what I got. The aroma was quite possibly the best of any stout Ive ever tasted. The flavor was smooth at the start and bitter sweet towards the end. I definite "wow" moment in my beer tasting career.

UPDATED: MAY 24, 2010 Pours a midnight ebony color and topped with creamy milk chocolatey brown head from the 750ml. bottle courtesy of thejon375 (thanks, Mike!): Nose of... holy crap!!! I just spilled half my Hunahpus all over the desk and keyboard! Fuckkkk!!!! Rerate 20 mins later: Keyboard still works! Aroma of rich dark chocolate, roasted malts, vanilla, dark pitted fruits, smoked wood, cinnamon, and now that I read the description I can definitely sense some juicy peppers in there. Deep chocolate flavors all around, mixed with generous portions of dark berry, dark malts, toffee, cinnamon, peppers, fig, raisins, prunes, vanilla, and alcohol. Velvety smooth right into the finish. Full-bodied, creamy/oily texture that slips right over the tongue. Very good, but dare I say, a little overrated? Drinkability: I love the stand-out peppery chile notes. Not overdone, perfectly balanced. Very unique. Pairing: Lots and lots of dark chocolate and thick beefy chili. Rebuy: Yeah. #438 on 04052010, DG.

12/30/2009:  Cigar City Hunahpus Imperial Stout...  Aroma:  Big, rich, and lush chocolate, mocha, and heavily caramelized malts with some sort of twist (probably from the peppers).  Appearance:  Black; opaque; lasting vibrant brown-mocha head.  Flavor:  Big and strong with plenty of roasted malt, cocoa, and coffee coming through; peppery spiciness; some dark chocolate notes; some alcohol through the nose.  Palate:  Medium to medium-full body; moderately thick; prickly feeling on the tongue; somewhat sticky.  Overall:  Interesting, but isnt really that spectacular despite its unique concoction of ingredients; again, a somewhat disappointing brew considering the hype.
Hand-bottled (draught) from daknole shared by alexsdad06.  Thanks Brad!  Rating #194 for this beer.

Bottle shared by badnewsbeers. Long anticipated, and finally opened on a lofty night of beer tasting. Pours the deepest opaque brown/black with a medium cream to ochre head. Surprisingly subtle nose with burnt caramel and firm pickly peppers. Spritzy body with slightly tart chocolate, coffee, and bitter roasted malt meshed with pickly, almost sour chiles. Vanilla is prominent mainly in the finish. A rich beer with nice mouthfeel and good complexity, but the peppers struggle to play well with the base beer, and end up dominating the experience in memory. Not one of my elite imperial stouts, but a very good one, and a pleasure to sample.

So, the Hunahpu has arrived. Bottle shared by Eric. Pours a black color with one of those wonderful dark brown heads that always foretell good things to come. The aroma was mostly sweet cocoa, chocolate, rich vanilla, slight spices. The taste was very nice; mostly upfront with huge blasts of cocoa, rich and heavy chocolaty goodness. A tingle of warm is throughout, but it is not from the alcohol but burns slightly in the throat from the pepper. Nice addition. Nothing overdone. Very good.

Small sample at DLD. The appearance is a rich deep black. The flavors and aroma really came through strong with deep dark dried fruits. Prunes, dates, raisins. Some nice chocolate hints too. The flavors werent quite what I was expecting but a really good brew. Perhaps open for a little too long. Would love to get a bottle to enjoy some more of this.

Generously shared by emacgee, who Ill emulate in rating this for 2K. Very hefty pour, thick like a milkshake, with heavy oils and intense lacing, a dank coffee colored head, and almost grain-like sediment visible. Its like the death metal of imperial stouts, Zhukov staring down the Mayan apocalypse. The aroma is rich and heady just like the base, but I was getting strong notes of coffee flan along with the sharp spices that are oh so inviting. Super creamy mouthfeel, a bit slick and grainy in a way that seems fitting. The taste is just so complex. Theres such depth and character in Zhukov anyways, but I love the way the taste of charred wood and tons of pepper take this to a delicious next level. Love to swirl it around, and the mouthfeel becomes pleasantly lactic after time. Dry finish, chili-tastic in every way. This is superlative.

Bottle shared by footbalm 
Appearance: Pours black with a dark tan head and nice looking lacing 
Aroma: Dark malts and sweet chocolate 
Taste: Silky mouthfeel, dark malts and dark chocolate 
Very nice, smooth drinkability. Well balanced.

Bottle sample at DLD 2010 shared by Bobby from Cleveland. Pours pitch black with a medium brown chocolate milk head. Roasty aroma with dark fruits and plenty of chocolate. Roasty and chocolatey flavor with dark fruit and a bitter spicy finish.

Bottle from drowland via Cavie.  Black pour with a thick, brown head.  Aroma is milk chocolate, bitter cocoa, alcohol, tons of coffee, licorice, and black pepper.  Taste is creamy, licorice, sour candy, chocolate, coffee, almost beefy, spices, and peanut butter.  Big coffee finish.

One of the few beers I took notes on at Dark Lord Day. 22 ounce bottle served into a 4 oz tasting glass. Dark black and opaque with a think brown head. Malty coffee in the smell. Chocolate malt balls with a bit of an orange and tangerine twang to it. Dark fruits like plums and raisins along with chocolate and vanilla notes. Full bodied, but light and creamy on the tongue. Smooth, nice dry finish. Certainly worth another taste -- would be a nice beer to have after dark or with a chocolate dessert.

bottle thanks to ericandersnavy.  pitch balck with a deep espresso almost red colored head, coats a glass ridiculously. great on the palate, huge flavors of roasted malts, chocolate, chilis in the end, raisins and so much more going on here.

Pours black with brown head.  Dark like expedition. Aroma of dark chocolate, vanilla, coffee, and chiles. That is it. Flavor of chiles, vanilla bean, cocoa, dark chocolate, toffee. Very heavy. Pure desert beer. Thick, chewy, filling.

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2013 750 ml bottle shared by foppa78 and the KC Beer Saints- thanks again, guys! Pours a motor oil, almost-black, dark brown color with a small brown head. Aroma of dark chocolate, roasted malts, vanilla, dark fruits, and a bit of smoked wood. The flavor follows suit, and I notice the cinnamon is present here, and the berry fruits stand out as well. A lot of chocolaty goodness. Full-bodied, with low carbonation and an oily mouthfeel. Re-Rate: 7/27/12. Yeah, this needed a re-rate, and what better occasion than a full vertical and horizontal? We had a 2012 back to a 2010, and even a 2009 that was bottled from a tap at a bar whose name shall remain secret. That one was infected, so Ill leave it out. The 2010 through 2012 are all doing great. 2010 was the roastiest of the bunch, and the one where the pepper was the most mellowed out. All have notes of roast, dark chocolate, fudge, and pepper, without as much vanilla as Id remembered. 2011 had by far the most chocolate in it, getting roastier and more peppery as it moved along. 2012 had the most pepper, and was very smooth throughout. Medium-full bodied, with moderate carbonation. Fantastic imperial stout. One of the greats. Re-Rate: The 2013 version is solid but not what it used to be.

Wowzers!  Bottle shared by jbye4334.  Pours opaque with a large, dark brown head, lasting with good lacing.  Aroma is dark chocolate, caramel, toffee malt, cinnamon, peppers, vanilla, light alcohol, figs, and prunes.  I could smell this all night and not get tired of this wonderful aroma.  Flavor is chocolate, dark malt, cinnamon, peppers, vanilla, alcohol, fig, raisins, prunes; smooth and velvety.  Full body, creamy texture, moderate carbonation.  This one lives up to the hype.
bomber shared DLD-black pour -brown head -aroma and taste of vanilla, roasty, peppers-smooth peppery finish that lingers

Sampled at DLD. Thick black pour with a rich dark brown head. Aroma was amazing as well as the taste. Chocolate, cocoa, smoke, coffee, vanilla. You get a bit of the pepper at the end, but nothing overbearing. Definately a beer for anyone to try that likes Impys.

Bottle tasting at DLD. Youll have to forgive me for my less than thourough tasting notes... a drunk taster with a destroyed palate does not, a proficient rater, make!
"Chocolate, vanilla, dark fruit, some smoke... been hearing alot, very good but not amazing." <--- Official tasting notes, probably the longest response to a beer I wrote all day, lol.
This was a darn fine beer, though just a bit overhyped.  It was a pleasure to try some from a fellow RBer at DLD after trading my only bottle away for some Nemesis.  Id be happy to get ahold of more!

UPDATED: APR 28, 2012 2012 Batch, score stays the same.
Appearance:  Pours black,like motor oil with a small cap of tan froth.

Aroma: Vanilla, hot peppers, green bell pepper  chocolate, chocolate chip cookie dough.

Taste: Bitter Chocolate, burnt roast, cinnamon covered almond, vanilla,oily hot pepper. Finishes more burnt that previous fresh batches.

Mouthfeel:  Thick. Full bodied.

Overall: Still in my top 3 favorite beers EVER. I think the pepper was more pronounced than the last two years, when fresh, and seemed a little hot alcohol wise. Drinking very well.

===============
2011 Batch
Appearance:  Pours an extremely viscous dark brown. Leaves behind an iodine like coating on the glass and virtually no head milliseconds after the pour.

Aroma: Chocolate liqueur,vanilla bean, dark chocolate and cinnamon.

Taste: Canoli, dark chocolate, toasted coconut, cinnamon covered almonds.

Mouthfeel: A little dusty/chalky, very thick with modest carbonation.

Overall:  I was amazed by last years batch, and this one topped that.

==============
2010s Batch, 4.7  10/10 - 5/5-10/10-4/5-18/20=4.7
Appearance:  Pours a viscous dark brown with a tan cap of head.

Aroma: Dark chocolate, vanilla, smokey malt and dark fruit.

Taste: Dark cherries, dark chocolate, smoked malt, vanilla and a little bit of cinnamon.

Mouthfeel: Goopy goodness.

Overall:  Amazing and complex. I absolutely love this beer. Better than MZ Imperial Stout by a little bit.

Bottle courtesy of dmac, thanks Dave! Shared with fordest, toncatcher, some other guy, and the rest of the East County crew. Poured a deep dark abyss black, with a reddish hue at the liquid level. Swirled around the glass created some brownish foam. Oily residue on the glass left behind. Aroma was chocolate, coffee, with hints of licorice, vanilla. First flavor to hit my tongue was coffee, finishing with chocolate, vanilla. I was unable to detect the chillis. I think more spice would have been good. A true masterpiece. We all enjoyed this one.

UPDATED: SEP 15, 2010 Bottle, sampled at DLD thanks to Hoosier Beer Geek. Pours black, iodine film coats the glass. This beer is as dark and rich as Dark Lord. Taste is very complex. Cocoa, fruity chile notes and the cinnamon and vanilla are just there with a hint to balance. The nose is a perfect match to the taste with a solid Mexican chocolate note, well balanced by alcohol. Its hard to put in words, but this is fantastic.

750ml bottle thanks to smith4498. Pours black with big thick dark tan head. Aromas of roasted malts, cocoa, and chocolate. Flavor is robust with thick dark malts, tons of chocolate, light cinnamon, light smoke, and very faint heat from chilis. Mouthfeel is thick and chewy. Not abrasive in any way. Flavors come together so well. It got even better as I let the bottle warm for a couple hours while on the way home from DLD. This beer comes with tons of hype and it lived up to it. Just like the rest of the CCB brews I have had.
Sampled at DLD 2010.  Very dense black with a deep brown head.  Big chocolate nose with some spicy hops.  Beefy flavor with some chocolate and leathery character.  Very palate coating.  Tasty.

UPDATED: MAR 8, 2014 I got to sampled this at DLD2010 thanks to the generosity of the Florida crew.  Very black pour with light brown head.  Aroma of dark chocolate, roast, some spice.  Flavor is thick and complex as hell.  Mostly rich, thick dark chocolate with a bit of heat from the peppers to keep it from getting too sweet.  Thick mouthfeel.  Absolutely awesome.

Re-rate: Think bodied, very mild chile heat, chocolate, nondescript sweetness. The mighty have fallen.

750 ml bottle

Once again thanks to either Mike or Eric for coming through with the beer of the night. None of them were bad but after having this the subsequent imperial stouts were framed in a different light. I was skeptical of the praise being heaped on Cigar City before but if this is any indication I cant wait to make a trip to Tampa some day.

Aroma / Appearance - Sticky sheets of dirty lacing formed an oily layer. Beneath was a deep brown head darker than some beers. At the bottom of the three layer cake was an oily black body. Inside was a rich blend of cinnamon, chocolate, vanilla beans, black coffee, and raspberries. Extremely sweet for an imperial stout this was certainly novel.

Flavor / Palate - Green pepper, cinnamon sticks, cigar ash, vanilla beans, and coffee cake fill the mouth with a rich dense liquid. The chewiness extends to the finish. Heavy on the malt this beer is one of the best I have tried and on par with Dark Lord, Speedway Stout, and other world class big beers. Assuming you dont have to trade away a first born child to get a bottle give it a try.

22 oz bomber from Bierkraft.  Very, very thick, sticky pitch black pour topped by a deep, dark brown creamy mousse.  The nose is absolutely loaded with rich cocoa and chocolate.  Thick and unctuous palate that is sticky, slick and palate coating.  There is just a kiss of chile flavour with lots of chile heat and a fairly pronounced cinnamon character on the back of all the big roastiness.  Warming brings more cinnamon and cocoa to the front and also lends a molasses character to the beer as well.  The ancho really comes up as well and the warm woodiness of the cinnamon starts to stick around and the beer comes together much better than it does when its cooler.  Rich and sticky and a very unique beer.

My first ever rating.  Might as well start off in style. Amazing beer. Aroma is a combo of sour fruit and charred rubble with a tinge of pepper spiciness. Mouthfeel is thick...super thick. Gets softer as it warms. Melds with the mouth as it approaches room temp. Flavor (to me) is Zhukov with big dark, partially sour fruit, teenie tiny tinges of vanilla and cinnamon, smokey charred goodness, all drenched in a blanket of bittersweet chocolate.  This may be my first rating, but it is far from my first beer...and Ive never had anything like this. World class, but very left of center. If you live for beer, make sure you try this one before you expire.

(750ml bottle thanks to ericandersnavy) jet black pour that coats the glass with deep brown hues, no bubbles. Nose of olives, spicy chiles, fudge and dark chocolate. Taste of vanilla, light chile heat, fudge, semi-sweet chocolate, graham crackers, tobacco, cinnamon with a thick, creamy, spicy finish. Excellent beer.

Courtesy of ericandersnavy. Black color with brown foam.  Very nice rich dark chocolate, black roasted malt, licorice herb aromas. Rich smooth mouthfeel. Black roast malt, dry bakers chocolate, licorice flavors. warming chili taste to finish.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: bottle, thanks to ericandersnavy, dark brown motor oil in color with long inky mercurichrome legs,  aroma has cinnamon, chocolate, roasty malts, flavors of cinnamon, spicy thai chili, cocoa, chocolate, thinnish mouthfeel

The aroma is very much suited to the style with burnt malt, chocolate, and coffee. The color is almost black with a thin brown head. The taste is like the aroma with a toasty finish. The palate is thick. Overall this beer has all the elements to fit the style and would stand up well to a cigar however it is lacking some of the flavors that I wanted and stronger on some I didnt.
a vast assortment of friuts, toasted mats, slight tartness and spicy peppers. rich palate with a choclate overtone that warms the heart.
There really is a lot going on here, but it all works so phenomenally well together.  Spiciness from the peppers follows up chocolate and coffee on the front.  Now I want another bottle!

Bottle shared by emacgee.  Thanks Ethan.  Very black oily pour with thick, stagnant deep tan head.  Great looking beer with an appearance thats hard to beat.  Nose is chocolate, cinnamon, pepper, roast.  Flavor is big and sweet with the spiciness of the peppers working well with the chocolate and molasses.  Its big and sweet without being too cloying like many many other recent RIS. Pretty tasty and one of the better CCB beers Ive tasted.

Bottle at miketds.  Thanks Mike!  Poured a dense black with a thick dark tan/brownish head.  Rich aromas or burnt malts, vanilla, chocolate and some earthiness.  Taste is unfortunelty one dimensional.  Straight forward chocolate/coffee and it is sickenly sweet.  There is some vanilla present, but it is overwhelmed by the other flavors.  I got no chili out of the beer.  I had approximately 4 oz. and that was tough to finish just because it was so sweet.  Glad I got to try it.
user_location: The Land of Milk and Honey, Ohio, USA

text:
Big thanks to ericandersnavy for sharing this bottle. 

The beer pours a inky black color with a brown, small head. The beer is oily and coats the sides of the glass. The aroma is roasted and burnt malt with dark fruit. The flavor is cinnamon, dark fruit, roasted/burnt malt, semi-sweet chocolate and pepper. The mouthfeel and thick and chewy and the carbonation is pretty low.

Bottle from Jimbo.   Smells fantastic:  Coffee, chocolate, vanilla, spices.   Darkest pour I think I have ever seen.  As someone said, "It looks like pudding."  Flavor was heavy on chocolate and coffee.  I was kind of hoping that the pepper flavor would shine through a bit more.  This was a bit on the dry side for me, but overall I thought it was very good.

750ml capped straight from Tampa...with the best titty bars in the nation!...via ibrew; thanks man!  Fuck me!...the nose is killer and this isnt a style that I really seek out and Im not talking about impy stout, cause this should be a spiced/herb...but, at any rate.  Big bitter 70%+ black cocoa with light yet perfect cinnamon and pepper spice.   All of this goin on in the flavor and I love this.  This is the best CCB beer ever!

Big hot peppery nose, black patent, dark bitter chocolate and roast. Lots of pepper on nose. Pours jet black with a dark brown head. Dark chocolate, peppery flavors, creamy milk chocolate, roast, char, and then more peppery notes - not. Hot but flavorful. Velvetty mouthfeel. Light heat.

750, capped. thanks dave! pours black with a huge dense thick burnt tan head. rich, roasty, coffeeish, smoky peppery nose. absolutely delectable nose. thick creamy body with soft carb. roast, coffee, dark chocolate, mild smoky pepper, some heat from both peppers and alcohol. long chocolatey roasty finish.

Bottle shared by emacgee for his 2000th rating.  Thanks for sharing, Ethan, and congrats on the milestone!  Pours black as night and oily thick with generous tan head.  Nose of ballpoint pen ink and cinnamon.  Also some chocolate and a hint at the peppers.  The peppers come out more in the taste, as does the chocolate and vanilla... its all very well balanced, even a bit fruity.  Good balance of sweet/roast/spice here, and the palate is amazing as well... almost fluffy despite how thick it looks.  Believe the hype.

bottle sent thanks to GoT.  poured black as can be with a copper head.  aroma was very decadent with fudge, slight chili, brownie, chocolate, and cinnamon.  flavor was just as outstanding as the nose but had an added character of coffee.  body was unbelievable, i took my first sip and was thrown off by the fact that i almost had to chew this beer.  i have had milkshakes thinner than this.  an awesome awesome awesome beer.  glad to be an honorary homer.

Poured Black like the stallion of midnight and stuff. I noticed a light tan fizz on top that disappeared fast, like Grease Lightning. Smelled different not like the uncle you rarely see, but more like a Mexican pinata before it is filled, not really but it sounds fun. I guess the smells are from the chiles? The taste is blended nicely with hints of nutmeg or cinnamon, chocolate (unsweet), the blend of chiles and finishes quite dry.

Thanks to drowland for this one, my 2000th rating. This immediately pours one of the most visually impressive brews Ive ever seen, the color of tar and viscosity of oil with a turbid head the color of charred wood.  Nose is earthy and peppery, bakers chocolate, mild roast, molasses and a mild sweetness, coffee. Not nearly as forward or impressive as the flavor. Nice  pepper and bakers chocolate pairing in the flavor, coffee and roast, molasses, sweet, some grain bitterness, mild alcohol. Palate is very viscous and thick with a smooth capsaicin heat and alcohol coming through.

750mL courtesy of Travlr. Pours ink well black with a head so dark brown it looks Martian red. Jesus. Very nice lace. Aroma is grapes, smoked meats, barbecue ribs, bacon. Interesting mix. Taste is fresh grapes, raisins and moves to a chalky, powdery finish. I think the base beer here, Zhukov, is one of my least favorite Imperial stouts. The Hunahpu treatment is a shoe in for an amazing beer, but the base beer is just so bad that you cant hide from it. Maybe do the Hunahpu treatment to the 110K.

750 ml bottle from the brewery tap.  Black, second darkest brown head I have ever seen.  Aroma of grapes and chili peppers.  Taste is thick, chewy chocolate and cocoa nibs, bacobits and ribs.  Interesting and complex, lots of flavors going on.

Very big thanks to spacecoyote for this. The beer in the glass looks awesome. Deep black like mtor oil, nice brown head. Starts very, very strong, intense malty with notes of liqorice, chocolate and strong coffee. Finish more bitter, still very intense. Also quite scratchy-woody. Goes down warming. A great beer!

Bottle thanks to ericandersnavy. Disclaimer: I think a lot of CCB beers are a bit over-rated (they are all solid, but some are not as amazing as some people wood claim). I loved BA Hunahpu. This not as much. Whatever. One persons opinion, right?. Pours with a deep brown head and a black body.  Glass coating. Aroma is ashy, tobacco, earthy, chocolate nibs, cinnamon. Taste is really chalky, chocolate, light spice, fudge. Syrupy, light bubbles. Rich.

Green, acetaldehyde nose, some chocolate, roast and coffee underneath. Very, very sweet taste, lots of raisin, tons of dark chocolate and caramel. Very rough and chalky texture to go along with the chewy unfermented sugars. Total mess.

750 ml bottle shared by mreusch. Pour is a deep syrupy black with a 1/2 inch dark khaki head. Head falls fast was splotchy lacing. Aroma of roasted malt, soy, and some alcohol heat. Taste is the roast, sweet malt and then a bit of the soy from the nose. Some dark dried fruit in the back - Eugene said prune, and that sounds about right.  Also a slight hint of grainy cinnamon.  The alcohol is better integrated in taste than nose, though still present. Sweetness cloys a bit in the finish. Palate is medium to heavy bodied, low carbonation and a hot finish. Thanks for sharing this one Matt.

Bottle shared by MrPickles...thanks Andy! - Pours jet black with a deep brown head. Smells dark and roasty, with sharp alcohol notes. Pretty one-note and disappointing, given the gushing from previous rates over the smell. Taste is much better, with a bit of molasses sweetness up front, transitioning into some smoky roast, burnt charcoal, and a touch of peppery heat on the finish. Smooth and really big, but the sweet/burnt combo is a bit bruising. The heat is unique, but not enough to make this any more than average.

750ml bottle, with thanks to both gunhaver and Ibrew2or3 for bottles.  Pours a thick looking oily dark black with a moderate dark brown head.  Aroma is mostly heavily roasted/burnt malts, with some cinnamon, vanilla, light pepper and chocolate behind that.  Flavor is similar with the heavy roast throughout, and more background cinnamon, a little vanilla, some cocoa, and maybe the slightest pepper heat if I really look for it, but overall the burnt/roast malts mostly push any nuance out of the way.  Decent enough, but was hoping for more complexity and dimensions with the treatments.  Thanks for the chance to try guys!

25.4 Oz bottle Thanks to dchmelas Super Six-pack shipper! YOu are a GOD!
Evil Dark ominous pour. Bring it to your lips and think of heaven. coffee, cinnamon Chocolate and that chilli taste is brought down by the Vanilla! The smoky rich pallet is a pure delight and should not be washed down by any other impostor stout! Enjoy!

25.4 oz bottle.  Dark brown with a creamy tan haze.  Brown stains remain on the glass with lacy specks.  Nose is dark chocolate, black olive, fudgy coffee and vanilla with spicy hints.  Full body; chalky, almost gritty, with a mild buzz.  Taste is huge chocolate, cinnamon, licorice and vanilla with toasted coconut coming through in the finish.  Subtle chilis with a bit of heat coming out long after.  Yum.

UPDATED: MAY 9, 2010 750ml Bottle. Pours black as night with a nice cocoa head. Smells of coffee, roasted malts, dark chocolate, and slight aroma of pepper and cinnamon. Full bodied, wow, so big and smooth. Flavors are full of dark coffee and chocolate, cinnamon, nice caramel sweetness, and a nice kick at the end with the chillies. Slightly bitter at the end as well. Awesome brew.

Bottle shared by Kan, thanks man!  Pour is almost unbelievably thick, dark, and rich.  I have never seen anything like it.  Also a very nice, full dark brown head that lingered for quite a while.  Best looking pour I have seen to date.  Aroma is more subtle than pour but still big.  Lots of molasses, roasted malt, and brown sugar.  Also notes of vanilla, light spice, and a background fruitiness that I think comes from the chilies.  The chili aroma is not too evident beyond that.  The flavor is also huge roasted malt balanced by molasses tones, vanilla, and a light chocolaty component that rounds out the flavor.  Again, not really much action from the chilies but an amazing beer nonetheless.

75cl Bottle, brought to Amsterdam by GodOfThunder, thank you so much for this gem! Black colour, pours like motoroil, deep brown head, the brownest Ive ever seen. Aroma of loads of roasted malts, chocolate, sweet vanilla, light cinnamon, more spiciness. Flavour is sweet, vanilla upfront, hard roasted malts, lots of bitter chocolate and milk chocolate, a hint of cinnamon, slight peppery burn on the tongue, roasted bitter finish. Fullbodied, prickly but smooth and fat mouthfeel. Very very good indeed. No homerism detected here.

saved approximately half of a 750 which spontaneously cracked in my cellar weeks after its safe return from tampa.  served at cellar temp.  still a few wisps of lace laid about the top of the beers surface, otherwise expected opaque pour with seemingly zero lacing.  aroma is devoid of booze even completely unchilled.  cornucopia of aromas speak to me: raspberry, grape and big organic earthy note similar to tobacco.  chocolate is the star, this stuff like like glue and motor oil mixed, the glass is filthy and the lip is super sticky.  chocolate is the most tantalizingly sweet example ive ever sampled until its gone and your mucky palate notices not the burn but the actual flavor of the chilies lingering on the roof of the mouth.  a second bottle (which was still intact at last check) is currently cellared off premises but assuming it has and continues to survive a proper sample will amend this rating in a few weeks.
The aroma was out of this world.  Dark body and an almond/tan colored head. This brew lived up to the hype.
Awesome beer, spicy flavor with a dry coffee finish.  Almost dark enough to stain your glass!
Bottle from 5 points.  Beautiful pour.  Sweet, malty aroma.  This is one full-flavored brew.  Sweet, dark chocolate, cherries, vanilla, smoky/spicy peppers.  Very nice brew.

Bottle, many, many thanks to Dmac. Pours out black with a brown almost rust tinged head. Very intriguing aroma of Ancho pepper(no its not just the label, I cook with the stuff all the time), light sugary sweetness, chocolate and some roast. Taste is extremely complex, with a real lot going on. Smooth, very full, but still smooth and velvet-like mouthfeel. Chocolate, light roasted malts, smoky pepper, vanilla, light earthy notes, some light caramelized sugar sweetness all come together in harmony and make this one hell of an experience to drink. Lots of hype for this beer, and rightly so.

UPDATED: SEP 29, 2010 Supremely dark body with a cinnamon-orange head.  This one delivers everything it claims, in both the nose and the flavor.  Cocoa, chiles, vanilla, etc ...  I do not need to elaborate on this because everyone else already has.  Nice heft, thick mouthfeel, and incredibly well-balanced.  This is a true achievement ... unique,  bold, and extremely well-crafted.  I fear this one has been muddled because of all the controversy.  Ignore and/or forget about all that nonsense.  To put it crudely ... you take a spicy burrito and a rich chocolate cake ... smash them together ... and somehow it works!  Innovation and experimentation leads to greatness.  Good job guys.
Thick ,tasty and fantastic with a dark as night pour and little tan head,taste of chocolate and sweetness overall a well balanced beer.CHEERS!

bottle shared on a balcony in clearwater, fla- the hype is certainly there, but with this brewer, all credit is fully deserved- thick as crap- never tasted a more balanced or well done imp stout- the chili presence, or lack thereof, was the only disappointment- big time chocolate at first- roast for sure- vanilla bean ever present- a real delight- how long did this age- are we sure it was 11 percent. Damn.

Talk about complex...

Had out of a growler and bottle at the Rosso Batch 2 release. Thanks to whomever brought these.

Pour was jet black with very little mocha head, no lace. 

Aroma was incredible coffee and cedar aroma, hints of chocolate. 

Flavor had an incredibly complex array of currants, plum, tobacco, and wine flavors. Overall, relatively sweet but this was balanced well.

Very thick imperial stout that drinks very well for the ABV. A fantastic beer that Id love to get my hands on again.

Bottle shared by Josh.  Thanks!  I have been wanting to try this one.  Pours oily thick black with dark tan head.  Aroma is dark roast, cinnamon, spicy pepper, some chocolate, and coffee.  Dense mouthfeel.  This beer coats the glass its so thick.  Flavors follow the nose and meld together perfectly.  There is a touch of heat that I sense in the back of the throat, but its not overpowering.  The pepper flavor I think is a real nice touch with the cinnamon and vanilla flavors that tickle my taste buds.  Great stuff.  More please!!

750ml bottle pours an oily, opaque black with a thin, creamy, brownish red head.  Aroma has raisins, dried chiles which some thought smelled like figs, brown sugar, some like spice.  Flavor is big on the raisin, fig, dried dark chile, brown sugar, spices, a touch of earthiness, light tobacco, pears, peach, dried cherries, and the cinnamon comes out when the beer comes up to room temperature.  The chile throws a lasting tinge of spice in the back of your throat.  Theres also a lasting sweetness and a little dryness.

Theres an almost medicinal quality (I assume imparted by the peppers mixing with the alcohol) to the aroma which also features plenty of sweet malts and cocoa.  Opaque black body is topped by a decent brown head that receds to a lasting cover with some sudsy lacing.  Flavour is thick milk and dark chocolate.  bitterness creeps in and becomes strong without you noticing until it has fully developed.  Theres a peppery spiciness that tingles the tongue and lips.  Alcohol is not notable in the flavour but definitely warms the chest.  Full body with pleasantly low, soft bubbled carbonation and very sticky texture.  Really quite impressive.  Bottle enjoyed  with Beershine, fiulijn and Oakes.

20100326 750ml bottle shared with TommyTilt, also on tap at Cigar City during RBWG. Pitch black with incessant, thick brown head that laces in patches, and, yes, better looking than the average IS. Aroma is full of vibrant pepper notes, shocking actually, and its a gorgeous match with the rich cocoa and slight cinnamon. Body is as rich and coating as old motor oil with a lingering sticky feel and late throat tingle from the peppers. Intense and lovely. Flavor is intensely roasty, chocolately, and with perfect interplay of spicy, peppery heat, pepper flesh, and roast, spicy Mounds bar. I went into this thinking it was probably overrated and just a better than average impy, but dammit if this isnt probably the most well done and beer-geek pandering bottle of delicousness Ive come across in a long time.

Red velvet cake color. Left about a finger width of dark copper colored head. Complex aroma of dark cocoa and coffee. Could really taste the green chile flavor as the beer rolled over my tounge. Got the heat at the back end with exhale.  Full bodied beer and left a pb&j feeling on my lips. Shared a 750ml bottle with willblake.

Rating #900.  LIVE RATE!  Huge thanks to dakine for sharing the goodness.  Pours a viscous black color with an intimidating reddish-brown head.  One of the best looking beers Ive ever seen.  Smells richly of green chiles, milk cocoa, and coffee grounds.  Tastes overwhelmingly of each with added notes of toasted malt, pepper jack, cough syrup, and soy sauce.  I really didnt think this could meet my expectations, but IT DOES.  FML.

750mL bottle from the release party (RBWG!) into a Cigar City snifter.  The aroma is extremely sweet with some soy and a noticeable dose of peppers going on... vanilla floating around in there too.   The flavor is extremely sweet with chocolate, roasted malts, dark fruits, and more. A certain ashiness comes with warmth as well.  The peppers come through with a hint of burn in the mouthfeel, which is well carbonated but still quite thick. Yummy!

on tap at CCB, pours black with a medium tan head.  Rich roasted malt and bakers chocolate aroma.  Flavor is very rich and creamy with a nutty black pepper in the background and a bitter molasses in the finish.  Top notch.

Draft @ Cigar City Brewings Hunahpu release. Pours black with creamy brown head. Aromas of roasted malts, coffee, cocoa, cinnamon and vanilla. Flavors of roasted malts, heat from chili peppers, coffee, cocoa, cinnamon and vanilla. Full body with verly little carbonation and a creamy mouthfeel. Excellent!
beautiful and thick dark brown color poured into a sifter.  great smell, definate vanilla.  wonderfuly smooth feel.  incredible!  sweet and bitter all at the same time.  great beer!!

C. Hard to see clarity when the beer is Black
H. Dark Black
N. Coffee, Cinnamon, Chocolate, hints of Vanilla

Alright this is why we came to Tampa. While I have had this beer before at craft festivals I have never actually reviewed it. Love the nose of this beer, it has such strong scent of coffee and cinnamon. It is hard to compare that odor, but it makes me happy. After first sip you can taste the cinnamon, coffee, and a hint of brown sugar and vanilla. Pretty complex and matures well while reaching room temperature. I would say slightly chilled is a great temperature for this 11% ABV beer. It is very smooth and easy to drink. Not an extremely thick Imperial stout. WowIm really happy that I came to Tampa and am able to pick up some bottles of this beer. I personally think it is going to become AMAZING after a few years in the cellar.

comments taken from DosBeerigos

(Draught)  Pours an opaque black body with a medium brown head.  Aroma of roasted malt, chilies, vanilla, and chocolate.  Flavor of licorice, roasted malt, chocolate, earth, anise, cinnamon, caramel, and chilies.

Bottle! 3 days after release in 2010. Poured in Snifter and Poured thick and creamy with a huge head. Nose of Cocoa and slight Vanilla. Silky feel rolling around my palate. Just plain amazing and only gets better as it warms up during the drinking process. Overall my favorite Imperial Stout.

Pours out thick black goop with slight brown bubbles. Smells sweet and roasty. Lots of chocolate cocoa flavor with a spicey flare. Notes of coffee, vanilla, chilis, and dark chocolate. Lots going on here. Sticky sweet finish.  Great stout one of their best.

75cl bottle.  Medium brown head that mostly dissipates atop a motor oil black body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, rich cocoa, some vanilla, cinnamon, chili pepper.  Taste is sweet, cocoa, dark chocolate, some chili pepper, light vanilla.  The chili burn is noticeable, and while it builds slightly in intensity, it never overpowers.  Sticky full body.

Huge thanks to mashmaster for sending a hand bottle of this one. Shared with a few deserving friends. Pours deep black with a burnt mocha head - beautiful, and the carbonation held up really well in the hand-bottle. Roasty aroma, and a lot of the sweetness shows through - vanilla and chocolate, with a subtle hint of the complexity underneath. The taste is really a myriad of different flavors moving through stages in your mouth. Traditional notes of chocolate and coffee are quickly compounded with peppers. Roasted, even smoked peppers. More chocolate shows up with waves of vanilla, and then the spice builds. It sizzles in your mouth, then fades into a wonderfully smooth chocolate, melting away and leaving a mild tingling sensation behind. For any Seattleites, this is like a Theo chili chocolate bar. So complex - there are so many layers in here. It may be a little hot - but Im a big fan.

pours this jet black with a tan head that stuck around alot longer then expected.  smells very stoutey.  smells of licorice chocolate and a hint of peppers and alcohol. tasted very stickey.  tasted alot like chocolate licorice and slight peppers.  very good.

UPDATED: MAR 14, 2010 on tap @ CCB event RNH.  This and Maduro Oatmeal Raisin were probably the stand-out beers of the event for me- tons of chocolate, roast, and light chili pepper flavor in the aroma and taste - nice raisiny dark fruit character.  Although big and sweet, it was balanced nicely with hop bitterness.

Draft at CCB.  Thought I would add this as my 100th rating.  I was very excited to try this.  Pour appears like motor oil with minimal head served in a tulip glass.  Served too cold, but oh well.  Aroma holds oak, chocolate, vanilla, and bourbon.   Flavors are simiar with brown sugar, molasses and some peppery notes as well.  Some bitter hops in the finish.  Great IS.
UPDATED: MAR 23, 2010 pours a beautiful black with a light brown head . aromas of coffee is huge. coffee,chili peppers,and brown sugar flavors. nice velvety mouthfeel. very nice beer

UPDATED: JAN 7, 2017 JANUARY 2017 RERATE (2015 bottle): Funny to see my old notes. My imp stout tastes have clearly changed and my score keeps going up for this. I now drink and like bourbon for one thing. Perfectly balanced rich molasses, cocoa bitter, light touch of the hot pepper, cinnamon. Great stuff.  MARCH 2014: Vertical kindly shared by Lance up at Proof (dude, thanks). Very interesting to try these side by side: ( 11 - musty, 1st); (12 - 4th, easily worst); (13 - soy - 3rd); (14 - 2nd close to 11);  ORIGINAL RATE, 3/11/2010: My first run at this - going to the bottle release tomorrow - this one on tap at the dubliner.  Ive had the Zhukovs and this is a fair bit different.  Ill give a more proper rate soon, but this is my initial impression score.  ReRate:  had this a few times now and this is my last bottle from the release party at the brewery.  Giant aroma of cocoa, coffee, peppers and vanilla.  Rich tastes of dark chocolate, burnt coffee, wood, vanilla, tobacco and the peppers.  This is a complex brew for sure.  Finishes up slightly sour - but still dominated by the ashy bitter and pepper tastes.  Its an interesting experience for sure.  I love the Zhukov because its so drinkable and complex.  This is much more of a sipper.

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2010 This is a huge brew. Big nose of alcohol, roasted malts, coffee and bittersweet chocolate. Flavor is big and bold, lots of roasty bitterness. Thick body, could coat a spoon, crazy. Extremely smooth, faint spice, cinnamon, and pepper at the end in the back of my throat. Creamy and delicious.

UPDATED: AUG 19, 2010 Growler shared from Big Z Beverage for our Pre-Night of the Living Ales Tasting. A big thanks (once again) to Alex for breaking this one out along with all the other epic beers we had.

A - Pours black, tan head (a fingers-worth), good retention, and some lacing along the sides of the glass. A slim cap of head on top.

S - Very pronounced chocolate, some chili spices (not overpowering though), vanilla, dark fruits.

T - Lots of chocolate on the palate. Very very chocolatey rich mixed in with some chili notes. Somehow, for me, the combo works. Ive never had a stout with such a real pronounced chocolate notes. Sweet and spicy finish.

M - Full bodied, rich, smooth, light carbonation. 

D - I drank several pours and it was just as good (if not better) after every pour. Im looking forward to trying this in the bottle to see if it differs at all. The hype on this one is well-deserving. Possibly my favorite Imperial Stout Ive ever had (beats Bells Black Note, IMO).

Poured at Stogie and Stout as well as FBG Beerfest.  Its like a delicious dark chocolate bar in beer form.  To be honest, i was skeptical since there was so much hype about this beer.  Rarely to things live up to that kind of raving.  But this beer is truly fantastic.  Thick and rich with a hint of the peppers and luscious with chocolate.
Draft at Brewvival: Woody aroma, not strong. Motor oil black, thin brown head, viscous. Woody soy sauce, cherry, smoked meat flavor. Soy sauce finish. Rather salty, but in a good way

UPDATED: APR 6, 2011 2011 bottle on 4/6/11.  pitch black pour with a bright tan head.  big chocolate nose with cinnamon, vanilla and roasted malts.  medium to full body with a spicy pepper front and smooth chocolate sides filled with coffee, vanilla and cinnamon.  the pepper level is perfect... blends very well with the chocolate and doesnt overpower the body/palate.  rich, roasted finish with more chocolate and coffee notes.

sample from the bottle @ GABF on 9/18/10.  pitch black pour with a thick tan head.  big roasted nose with spice & peppers.  thick body - syrup feel.  roast finish with layers of chocolate and coffee.

Draft sample @ Brewvival on 2/27/10.  Surprise keg at the festival!!!  So happy Ive got to try this one - and I had a few pours.... Pitch black pour with a thin tan head... roasted malt aroma with spice... solid body with licorice, raisin, dates, peppers, and cinnamon... there is a lot going on here... and it all works well together.  sweet bitter finish with a vanilla softness.  I would love a bottle of this...
Draft brewvival.   Viscous dark pour with a thin beige head.  Ancho pepper and light cinnamon on the nose.  Flavor is chocolate, coffee, cinnamon, light smoke, and vanilla.
Tap at Rattle n Hum. Sweet vanilla pepper nose. Spicy and  powerfully strong nose. Flavor follows the nose with spice notes and  big roast malts lots of vanilla. Spicy bitter finish quite good.
8oz pour at the RnH event.  Poured was a deep black with a thick beige head. Roasted malts, tobacco, cocoa, coffee in the nose.   Taste is tobacco, vanilla, cocoa, ash, roasted malts. .

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2010 Bottle.  Poured an opaque brown color with a tan head and oily legs.  Aroma of milk chocolate, cinnamon/nutmeg, brown sugar, spice, and sun flower seeds.  Roasty spiced flavor.  Chocolatey.  Medium bodied and silky on the tongue.Tap @ Rattle n Hum.  Poured black with a tan head.  Roasted malt aroma with cocoa and mild notes of coffee.  Light alcohol and ash.  The flavor was of dry roasted malt with a mild roasted bitterness.  Light side of medium bodied.

Bottle generously shared by Sparky27...thanks Eric!!!  Liquid coal pour produced only a whispy dark caramel cloud that floated on top of the body (hand bottle).  Bonus point for it staining the inside of the glass.  Aroma is pungent Godiva, molasses, roasted coffee, and vanilla.  Flavor is chocolate forward, but also delivers black licorice Jelly Bellies, burnt marshmallow, brown sugar, and balancing hops.  Although the pasillo & ancho chili peppers werent noticeable, the cinnamon definitely had a nice presence which added tremendous complexity to the beer.  A little sweet and couldnt drink a ton (who am I kidding, of course I could), but this one was fantastic.

Tap @ RnH - thanks to Jay for sharing before I left for the night. Had this after the Ba version. The sweet chocolate comes out of the pepper-infused beer. Taking away the smokey wood reveals some nice sweetness.

This beer looks incredible, really looks like the perfect stout, nice dark thick body with a beautiful dark tan head. The nose is dominated by peppers, burns the nostrils a bit. This is a very chewy beer, not sure Ive seen anything pour this thick before. Some bakers chocolate and an ashy burnt tone to it. The peppers are there in force. They are slightly distracting and Id love to see them toned down just a bit (barrel aged version maybe?) however they really make this unique. I couldnt drink great quantities of this beer, which might make the high rating seem a bit off, but its very well executed and so unique it is deserving of it.

[Bottle] shared by tytoanderso. Counter-pressure filled Bierkraft bomber pours inky black with a moderate super dark brown head that gradually dissipates into a few soapy bubbles. Aroma has a definite pepper presence, dark chocolate, roasty malts, French press coffee and some fresh coffee beans. Flavor is really strange and unique. Chalky and astringent bittersweet roasted malts, lots of spicy pepper, lots of dusty chocolate and cocoa powder, alcohol is slightly noticeable. The pepper is really interesting  lightly green but smoky and earthy overall with a light actual spiciness that really builds as I drink it. I dont get much for cinnamon or vanilla, but it doesnt matter too much. Long super astringent and bittersweet finish. Unique beer and one that Im happy to have had.

22oz Bierkraft filled bottle. I was unsure about this one, but all of the elements seem to work well together. Definite smoked pepper aroma. Bittersweet chocolate, vanilla extract, nutmeg. I know this hasnt seen the "humidor treatment" but I swear that I smell cedar. Maybe some molasses? Slight ash and char upon warming. It pours about as gorgeous as an imperial stout can get. Thick, oily liquid with a deep, rich, thick, mocha colored frothy, lasting head. Flavor is actually a very pleasant balance of smoky (not spicy) peppers and mild chocolate liqueur. Molasses, wet wood, more cedar (maybe its the cinnamon). The malt, chocolate, vanilla and peppers actually come together rather nicely. Viscous, but not cloying mouth feel with a slightly ashy and smoky finish. Unique and rather tasty! Thanks Jonathan!

Hand bottle from one of the best dudes on this site  thanks!  Pours pitch black with a thin tan head.  The nose is dark fruits, roasted malt, ashy cocoa, molasses and spiked coffee.  The taste is black licorice, molasses, burnt malt, dark chocolate, coffee and a nice bitter hoppy finish.  Medium semi-creamy mouthfeel.  Very good  worthy of the hype.

UPDATED: FEB 21, 2010 Cigar City takes NYC event at Rumble N Hum, on tap.  Had this the next day.  Big peppers, great dinkability and edge.  Very dark brown with brown lace.  CIgar wood and chocolate, but the pepper is paramount.

On tap at Rattle N Hum for their Cigar City event.  This was the last keg to arrive and was worth the wait.  Apparently the keg they were supposed to get didnt show and Patrick tracked one down through Mike I think.  However it got there, thanks guys for getting this.  Pours a viscous dark black with a thick tan head.  Chocolate, chiles, fruit, roast.  Medium bodied, full of spicy chocolate pudding flavors.  The subtle heat really shines here balancing out a style that often gets too sweet for its own good.  Smokey, chocolate, and more roast on the finish. Smooth and tasty.

UPDATED: APR 10, 2010 Growler from Big Z Beverage.  Pours black with a small but long-lasting dark tan/reddish head.  Super pretty head.  Aroma of bitter chocolate, lots of cocoa, tons of graham cracker (including some cinnamon), roasted malt, toffee, vanilla, oak.  Flavor is quite chocolatey up front with a definite peppery spice note and a chalky, chocolatey finish.  Graham cracker still present but less so.  As I continue to drink, the pepper/chile spiciness really starts to heat up my mouth.  This is one of the most chocolatey beers Ive ever had.  One of the most unique and well crafted imperial stouts out there.  Im proud to award this beer my first ever 5.0.
10/5/10/5/20 [5/5]

UPDATED: SEP 14, 2012 Draft at RnH in nyc. Pours a dark, dark black body with thin brown lacing. The aroma is delicious roast, coffee, chocolate, and pepper. The flavor includes all the same flavors notes in the aroma. Awesome first beer of the night. Bottle - sampled with Pat, Uncle J and Dad. Pours a pitch black motor oil oily body with nice chocolate lacing that lasts throughout the session. The aroma is dark chocolate, coffee, cocoa, vanilla, and cinnamon. Mouthfeel is syrupy with great notes of sweet chocolate, vanilla beans, coffee, maple, oak, and cinnamon. Great stout - Ill have to muster up the self-control to put one of these guys away for a few years.

UPDATED: FEB 20, 2010 On tap at RnH.  It was nice to get to try some of this.  I was wondering why CC offers 2 types of imperial stout, but the RB description explains that this is a spiced up version of the Marshall Zhukov.  This is a rich, potent imperial stout, with flavors of coffee, prune, raisins, cocoa, tobacco tar, a bit of citrusy tang, and drying hops. Spicy and woody, with a chili-hop tingle.  It is warm on the palate, and astringent too. Wow. A very interesting and powerful brew.

On draft at Rattle N Hum.
Pours a deep black with a small tan head.  Smells of chocolate, bitter coffeee, and a decent amount of peppers.  The taste has lots of bitter chocolate and espresso.  The peppers are also quite prevelant and build to leave a decent kick in your mouth by the end of the glass.  Overall a great stout with a ton of flavor and aroma.

Pours like black coffee with a creamy coffee head, smells like cocoa, wafers, licorice, brown sugar, molasses, basically it smells very sweet but not sickly so.  Taste is semi-sweet chocolate, with a floral hop presence, coffee, brown sugar, and spicy vanulla...the mouth is lacy and a little gritty towards the finish.  The alcohol is warming and welcome.

UPDATED: DEC 17, 2011 hand bottle and a big thanks to flossmoorbrewalum for sharing! pours black with creamy tan head. nose is rich with dark coffee, dark chocolate, and peppers. flavors of dark chocolate, licorice, chili peppers, coffee, slightly burnt malt going on, with a mild but lingering pepper in the finish. all flavors are in nice balance and this is very smooth beer...................sampled a few more times and loved the 11 vintage, just has everything working perfectly together, you can taste each spice added but nothing over powers, probably the best impy ever.

UPDATED: JAN 27, 2017 Tap. Holy cow, was this good! The malt is a heavy dose of toasted, bitter chocolate, coffee and molasses, medium resin for the hops, earth for the yeast, with hints of tar, alcohol and soy sauce in the background. Head is small, creamy, dark brown, with some lacing and great legs and is mostly diminishing. Color is black. flavor starts moderately sweet and acidic, then finishes moderately sweet, lightly acidic, heavily bitter and a touch sour. Palate is full, between creamy and syrupy, with a soft carbonation and a dry and astringent finish. Packed with a ton of flavors and aromas, nothing subtle about this beer. A superb Imperial Stout.

Many thanks to JoeMcPhee for sharing this - man, this is a pretty pour - viscous, black, dark tan head - cinnamon is very prominent in the nose, as are the chillies, but there are notes of dark chocolate and vanilla - full mouthfeel, soft carbonation - the flavor is rather smoky up front, followed by fairly potent chili pepper spiciness - sadly, the chillies also add a fairly pronounced vegetal character through the middle - bitter dark chocolate and cinnamon generate a quality similar to mexican hot chocolate - the spice from the peppers last through the finish, and a mild tartness and astringency develop - I want to love this beer, but I simply like it.

UPDATED: JUN 16, 2010 Bottled version:  Looks absolutely perfect.  Smells divine.  Taste is a lot different from how I remember, with the cinnamon standing out more, very complex.   God this beer is awesome.


On draft at the tasting room party.  The appearance was good but not great, I think that Id like to pour this into a snifter before deciding if it deserves a 5.  The nose has strong, strong chocolate that meshes well with some notes of vanilla.  Didnt detect much of the pepper until it got warmer.  The mouthfeel is extremely creamy and just divine, and the taste very closely follows the nose.  Theres a great blend of chocolate and vanilla with no coffee or burnt malt taste.  Dont notice too many hop flavors either.  Not too sweet, just right.  The pepper hits the back of the palate gently but isnt as significant as I expected.  Lived up to my expectations, and I cannot wait to try this again.  Also, its preposterously easy to drink two or three glasses of this.

Enjoyed at the Flossmoor Station RB tasting, 1/16/2010:  This poured a thick dark brown body capy by a short tan head.  The aroma was sweet roasted malt, chocolate, vanilla, sharp grass, and a dash of mild peppers.  The flavor was heavy, syrupy with the dark malt, complemented by vanilla, a hoppy bitterness, cocoa, anise, and damp wood.  The ancho came around near the end along wth a soft sour twist.  I never picked up on the cinnamon.  The finish was sweet/sour and peppery.  Nice.

UPDATED: DEC 4, 2011 22 oz bottle courtesy of fishingnet. Thanks, Ben! Pours a thick viscous black with a dark brownish head, laces ok and films. Aromas are a blast of dark roasty malts, cocoa, vanilla, a touch of peppery spice, a blast of bittering hops, coffee. Initial is big and bitter, hops and roasted malts, vanilla and dark chocolate is very dominant, in the raw, very bitter, the malts and hops take over, the light heat grows on the back of the palate, not being a shocker, moreso a light dusting, growing and complimenting the roast well. Bitter, thick and covering the palate well. The heat grows in the belly, but lightly, nothing to overtake the flavors of roasted malts, coffee, and chocolate with pretty prominent bitterness. Licorice and subtle chalkiness, the beer really works well for dessert. Very nice. Rerate pending - 2011 Bottles show lively spice and pepper, very nice. Bumped up .1 pts - Better than any of the oak/barrel treatments I had, the base stands on its own merits.

Chitown RB gathering Jan 2010: 22 oz handbottle graciously shared by Adam. What a nice way to start the hours of drinking... Basically opaque with a lasting tan head and very good lace. The aroma has notes of pepper, chocolate, vanilla, smoke, leather, anise, and cinnamon. The taste was more malt forward with the spicy components more of an accent than expected, that said the dark fruit and grassy hops work nicely. Some espresso and smoky notes as well. The mouth feel is a bit chewy and slightly aggressive, a tad chalky as well. This is quite nice and is the 2nd CC brew that actually met my expectations. Yummy!

First beer at the chicagoland ratebeer tasting.  22 oz bottle graciously shared by Flssmrbrewalum.  Thanks again Adam for putting this tasting together- I had a great time.  


Pours a deep brown with a small tan head.  Aroma has notes of coffee, molasses, vanilla, dough,  and smoked meat.  Off to a good start!  Flavor comes through with a nice flowing  tabacco, hot pepper (seemed more like jalapenos than chili peppers,) roast, and cocoa.  The hot pepper gives a nice complimentary bite to this.  Doesnt overpower or take away from the other attributes of the beer- like rogue chipolte ale, for instance. Nice body, sticky mouthfeel.  Pretty solid all around and tasty fo sho.  A great, complex stout where the heat and smoke work great together making this a very different beer from regular zhukov.  I enjoyed both regular zhukov and this quite a bit, but, if both were readily available,  I could see myself drinking the original zhukov on a more regular basis.  Likely goes great with a cigar.  Thanks again adam for sharing!

22oz bottle from a growler. Shared by Adam. Huge thanks.... Pours an oily black with a nice thin tan head... Aroma of smoke and ash, some added roast... Flavor is really lush and smooth with smoky chocolate alongside a mild degree of chili pepper heat that lasts long through the finish. Really smooth and velvety.

black with a minimal light brown head. solid. the spiciness slowly builds in the back of the throat without becoming abrasive or challenging. interesting execution of somewhat contrasting elements. mildly reminded me of mexican chilipop candies

Yes this is my favorite style but thats not why I rated this so high.......what a bomb.....so much going on.  Deep dark pour...just as you would expect from a serious IS.  The nose and flavor are off the charts.  The best I can say is it makes me remember what I loved about the IS style but with an extra kick.  The closest example would be the time in 2003 when I drank my first 2002 Speedway Stout....yum.

#500th rating! I would like to thank the person who shared this with the group but I dont know there name, thanks to the floridian who shared CCB beers @ Capones! Black pour with tan head.  Aromas and flavors galore, toffee, chocolate, oak, licorice, spices, peppers, and many i couldnt even begin to describe. And all the flavors blend so well. Drank at slightly warmer than cellar temp and still only a slight warming.

Tap at EDAs new place.  Pours a deep dark rich oily black with a dark orange-tan head- lasting.  Aroma is intense- loaded with chocolate, dark chocolate- and cocoa nibs edging with spicy peppers- chipotle, smoked peppers, ancho chillies- spices are more subdued as well as the actual peppers from a batch I tried this summer- slight cinnamon and vanilla is restrained which is nice.  Oily rich chocolate flavor, roasted barley, nutty cocoa nibs- earth, leather, spice, anise, licorice root, toffee and tobacco with more peppers and spices- The new batch is much more subdued, and not as unique as the sample from the summer at Cletus tasting.  Smooth and rich finish- and just really a great Impy stout.  Needs to go back to heavier spicing, more chocolate, and more peppers for the next batch!   If so- the rating will probably go back to a 4.5+

Bottle from daknole shared by alexsdad06. Poured a reddish black color with an average frothy brown head that mostly lasted with excellent lacing. Moderate to heavy roasted coffee, chocolate and spice aroma. Medium to heavy toasted chocolate malt flavor with a heavy dark bittersweet and small pepper bite finish of moderate to long duration. Full body with a smooth texture and flat carbonation. This is another standout beer.

UPDATED: MAR 16, 2010 on tap at Mr.  Dunderbaks. Smell is pure cocoa.  Nice dark chocolatey taste.  This beer is thick and oily.   Heat hits you right in the back of the throat after each sip.  I found my self drinking it faster than Id like,  just to stop the heat.  I didnt detect any  cinamon or vanilla.  Will revisit again.  A very unique beer to say the least.

DaSilky1 tasting (thanks for hosting, Todd!). December 13th 2009. 22oz Biercraft handbottle from who else: Daknole! Thanks Dakine!  Thats from Wetherel to me from Dak.  Pours big ole black with a thin light brown head.  Nose is sweet and chocolaty with a touch of those peppers.  Taste is great chocolate with a nice pepperiness and a touch of smoke.  Really nice, big rich malts, exceptional and different.

Tap at Mike (Eyedrinkales) place: Thanks! Opaque black pour with a thick strong brown head. Nice looking stuff. Rich tarry malts in the aroma- licorice, espresso, dark chocolate liqueur, and a spicy complexity of mainly cinnamon. Slick big body with a rich and spicy flavor. Tarry black malts with a smooth roast presence under a spicy peppery character. As it warms the cinnamon comes through nicely. Complex layers of spiciness with a mild spicy burn (not alcohol, but actual peppery spiciness) as it warms. Unique and awesome stuff.

wetherel "growler", just some other bomber filled up i believe?  odd growler laws in FL.  score seems low as this was near 5.0 to start, the ancho peppers add a cool smokey flavor to start, they end up adding quite a bit of heat that i personally dont enjoy, where others might give this ++ points for.  still, super complex nose, add the "stuff" they threw in this beer all made for a super complex, delicious and unique beer.  dasilky tasting, could of been best of the nite but the hot from the peppers knocked this down.  give me a scoop of vanilla ice cream and my score might change.  again a rate treat and thanks for byo.

DaSilky1 tasting (thanks for hosting, Todd!).  December 13th 2009.  22oz Biercraft handbottle from who else:  Daknole!  Thanks Dakine!  Two years of driving, traveling, trading, waiting in lines, and finally!  Ive tried all top 50 beers.  I never thought it was possible, but thanks to the new rating system, and the insanely awesome rare-beer producing brewers of San Diego, and WeeHeavySDs beer prowess, Ive been able to try all top 50 beers.  (3 more to all top 100).  Now its time to take a rest.
   Anywho, on to the beer:  Smells great.  What is this about the beer that smells great.  Some weird adjunct.  Im not sure.  Tons of chocolate.  Kind of reminds me of a malted milk ball.  The taste has some throat burn that lingers.  Originally, I thought it was alcohol burn, but now I think its more likely from the peppers.  Very, very good.  Very easy to drink.  One of my favorites of the night.  Excellent.

Pours a dark brown with a wispy yet thin brown head.  Nose is subtle with cocoa, raisin, and subtly smokey from the chilis.  The cocoa and the chilis combine in a very mole sort of way...but the super aggressive hopping keeps them from really coming together as the bitterness distracts a bit.  The cocoa flavors are pretty vivid though... the capsicum heat is a bit of a creeper as it at first is just a subtle scratchiness but after a while you can feel the heat throughout your mouth and throat.  The vanilla notes are nicely complimenting....and Im really digging the influence of the chilis, the chocolate, and the vanilla...almost a kin to a nice mole.  Other than the out of place bitterness here, this is a pretty nice beer.

Big thanks to Will for this!
Aroma is intensely chocolate.  Vanilla and alcohol also make their presence known, leading to an extract essence.
Taste has a ton of ancho making it very astringent- distractingly so.  Cocoa, bitter roasted malt, and hoppy pine round out the flavors.  
Finish is bitter cocoa, ancho chalkiness, and slightly cloying.
Good, and different, but not a huge success for me.

UPDATED: MAR 27, 2010 Rating #1300!!!  Hand Bottle, thanks to JW77 and Daknole. Pours black, with a brown head. Aroma is coffee, chocolate, caramel, cinnamon,  vanilla, and chilis.  Flavor is chocolate, coffee, chili peppers, caramel, cinnamon, and licorice. Heavy body. The heat (a nice amount, not overpowering), hits after swallowing at the back of the tongue and in the throat. Amazing flavors going on here. 
Re-rate with an official Cigar City bottle. Went for 4.4 to 4.8.

Huge thanks to tpd975 for sharing this during his recent trip to Philly. Ive wanted to try this one for a while and Im very thankful for the chance.

Pours pitch black and completely opaque with a frothy dark mocha/ chocolate brown head with good retention that slowly settles into a lasting ring which leaves sporadic spots of lacing behind.

Bitter sweet dark chocolate aroma with some slight earthiness, caramel and chocolate malt, licorice, subtle dark fruit, vanilla and a strong chili pepper presence. This adds a bit of spicy cinnamon/peppery character to the nose.

Chewy viscous medium body with lots of silky chocolate malt, toffee, coffee, vanilla, and slight hazelnut notes. There is an amazing spicy peppery chili presence in the finish which adds extra complexity to this unique beer.
